ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A lot of knowledge on various topics from the lectures such as cells, DNA, evolution, aging, cancer, microbes, pain signaling, addiction, opioid crisis, CRISPR and gene editing, climate change and so on. Also in section we covered interesting topics.

Absolutely nothing. This course prides itself on informing young scholars about the future of biology that could be applicable to their careers for the betterment of society. Let me tell you, though, that society is gaining absolutely nothing from this less than useless course.
I learned about topics in biology related to current events and some of the ethical issues surrounding these topics.
I learned the basics of GMOs, cell structure, etc.
Basic bio knowledge
Variety of biology topics and social aspects of them.
I learned a variety of "biology" topics such as cell physiology, cocaine use, and pain receptors. It was really a large variety of concepts.
I learned a lot of biology knowledge and how it's relevant to the world right now.

This course helped me to better understand the role biology plays in several aspects of our world, from opioid addiction to CRISPR gene editing. I am better able to understand biological concepts and connect them to real world problems.
I would say just past introductory-level knowledge of biology
A thorough background in many modern, relevant concepts in biology today. Examples include the lectures on CRISPR, Covid-19, climate change, and the opioid epidemic.
Interesting class
I gained an understanding of various things in biology and current applications in the world.

This course is a survey course in biology, with a specific focus on recent developments in the field. I thought it was very interesting to learn about the material and I do think I took away a lot from some of the more relevant lectures.
Learned about basic biological concepts and their applications in the real world.
i learned a lot about biology and its applications to the real world
I feel as if I am aware of general biological processes (I know enough to know that I dont understand completely). I am aware of the general politics and processes involved with scientific research.
I learned knowledge about elements of biology and how they relate the world
I learned about basic biology and some of the top issues and events in science relating to us today.
An understanding of how biology is present everywhere

I was able to develop the ability to connect biological concepts to real world issues. This will help me to understand the greater context of certain issues such as climate change or the Opioid Epidemic.
How to apply biology approaches to everyday life
I learned the basics of biology and why it's important to know about considering world events.
This was a great introductory course to bio that covered a wide range of topics.
Basics and foundations of biology
I learned about the fundamental biological process that explain life.

Learned a whole lot about the biological topics that are highly relevant to our lives, from plants/GMOs, to genetics, to cells, and so much more. Everybody should have the science knowledge presented in this class to be a productive member of society. This class is just a short step beyond "cocktail hour" biology, which is a great thing to know.

I learned many things about how biological processes work such as cancer, mutations, etc. I also learned about the social aspect of biology and attained the skills of reading through academic research.
I learned basic knowledge about the fundamental workings of cells, viruses, drugs, and more.
How to analyze sources, how experiments are conducted, significant and relevant ongoing projects in biology
Basic Bio knowledge relevant to current events
Basic understanding of drugs effects on the brain and cancer.
I learned various things about biology through this course.
You learn some bio topics: COVID, farming, genetic editing. Not much you wouldn't know if you had taken a decent bio course in HS, though.
I learned a lot of general stuff about bio, specifically concepts that come up a lot in my life or in the news that I now understand better.
I learned a lot in section! So much about new developments in the science community that was very interesting. In terms of academic skills, I didnt learn that much.
Learned a lot of human biology and the surrounding world. It has helped my understanding of the world.

I learned a basic understanding of a wide variety of biological topics, both on the cellular level and how they effect society at large. This meant both memorization of specifics and application of broad concepts to a variety of situations. This course demonstrated the connections between biology and society, in terms of politics, public opinion, and engineering.
I have had a good introduction to many scientific areas of study
Basic knowledge of biology and it real-life implications.
This class will teach you the basics of biological concepts.
Knowledge surrounding how biology affects everyday processes.

I learned some of the basics of biology and how to better understand subjects like disease, climate change and genetics. As someone who hasn't taken a biology course since high school, the class was a really effective introduction and I learned a lot.
This class gave a brief overview of important biological topics and social issues connected to them. We learned about cells, evolution, neurotransmission, COVID-19, and plants.
This gave me basic Biology and science background.
Basic knowledge of biology and biological concepts
Gained a lot of presenting skills

I learned more about a variety of biology topics, specifically topics that are relevant in our current world such as climate change, GMOs, COVID-19, etc. I learned the basic science about a variety of these topics but also their importance outside of just science.

Note that the topics you learn about seem to change depending on the professors teaching during your term. Generally though, learned about cell biology, plant biology, pandemics/COVID-19 etcs, and neurotransmitters/neurobiology as it relates to addiction
I learned about the basics of biology
I gained a knowledge of the biggest scientific issues of our time, sometimes on a very specific scale, which helps me feel informed about the world at large.
Advanced Biology beyond AP Biology
A lot of basic biology
In this course I learned a general overview of various relevant topics in biology.
Insight into a wide variety of scientific inquiry.
A multivariable understanding of different topics in modern science.

I learned about basic biology and the natural sciences.  A large emphasis was on the genetic components of biology (DNA, RNA, protein, genes, etc) but I enjoyed getting into the finer details of the subject.

In this course, I learned about biology and its impact on human life in the everyday world. We learned many details about complex biology and learned how to apply it to the world around us. I feel better equipped to speak on biological social issues in America, like the opioid crisis, climate change, or COVID-19.
I learned about different aspects of biology and their bigger implications in the world.

This course taught me how biology is in our everyday lives. This course gave me the knowledge of how our cells affect our lives. Also how pandemics like COVID affected peoples bodies and the environments food supply. This course has taught me a numerous of things that I will take on in the future.
Broad study of biological concepts.
Biology of cells, plants, drugs, COVID, and more.
I learned a lot about the mechanisms behind relevant scientific things on a molecular level which was really informative

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strenghts: great topics on biology and our world, was nice that the lecture speakers altered to keep the course fresh.
Weaknesses: some material was hard considering this is a bio class for non-stem majors. I'm especially talking about Professor Paulsen's lectures where we covered the nervous system.

The weaknesses of this course are too far and in between to describe in the space I have here, but I will try. Biology, the World and Us is not only the worst class in the MCB&D/MBB department, but by far, without question, the worst class offered at Yale College altogether. The professors and guest lecturers make science and biology seem like the most flaccid, unappealing topic in the world. Then, after droning on for 50 minutes twice a week, they make you dissect the most intricate topics that they didn't even scratch on during class. The weakness of this course can only be improved if the class was canceled.
Strengths: lectures are easy to follow, and there are no weekly assignments. Weaknesses: it is very hard to foresee what will be on the exams.
The course was not perfectly organized, but I understand that it was the first time taught in this format.
Strength was probably section because of my TF.

Strengths - Topics and lectures were interesting, like the variety of teachers, discussion section was fun
Weaknesses - Some teachers were better than others, tests questions were kind of odd sometimes
It's a worthwhile science gut that doesn't require too much brainpower. You won't have fun, but it won't be too painful either.
Ended up being far more difficult than I had expected. Tests were very hard. Material was interesting at times. Section felt very unnecessary/unrelated to the class.
Strengths: Very useful knowledge of biology and would always connect it to its relevance to the world right now.

This course engages students in a variety of interesting topics within science. The TAs are incredibly helpful and the sections help to further connect biology and the world. The weakness of this course, however, was the amount of information that was covered on the tests and in lectures. We did not fully explore the concepts we were tested on, which made it extremely difficult to prepare for tests.

The main strength is that the lecturers change. It is good because it means that you don't get bored so much. A weakness would be the random nature of the exam questions. Some of the questions are so strange and not really related to what we had learned.

Strengths: The subject matter is very interesting and engaging! Most of the lectures were very good, and discussion section is not necessarily another lecture. Lectures and exams are typically non-cumulative. 

Weaknesses: While typically at a more elementary level, some of the lectures could be much more technical than others. Studying for the exams was at times difficult, since the lectures aren't really cumulative/string together. Also, I didn't really feel prepared to read lots of scientific studies in advance for the final paper, which requires citing journal articles that can be incredibly specific and involve a learning curve on the subject matter, depending on topic.
The TFs and the professors don't seem to communicate enough so different sections will learn different things and whether or not the exam reviews will be helpful tends to be up in the air.
Good content

The course is designed around biweekly lectures and we have three tests. Sometimes, the connection between the lectures and test material wasn't the most clear and testing grading could be inconsistent. Also, the discussion sections could be more oriented to what the class was covering.

Strengths: I liked the rotation of lecturers to keep things fresh; I appreciate the emphasis on mostly relevant material to us as non-bio and mostly non-stem majors and felt as though I actually learned a lot about topics that are interesting, but that I never would been exposed to otherwise

Weakness: This course is surprisingly difficult - you do have to work very hard if you want to do well and even then its uncertain; on the last point, I would not say that this course is intellectually very challenging (it is to an extent, but that wasnt the main difficulty), the main challenge wa the way the class was set up - I dont feel like the three midterms were at all very fair and they seemed unnecessarily difficult and stressful.
I think the course was fine. Only thing I remember being frustrated by was that it wasn't clear what information we needed to have memorized (such as full names of proteins and chemicals).
i liked how the units were split up through different lecturers it was nice to hear from multiple people
This class is horribly organized, the content is not well explained, and the level of the content is way above a course meant for non science majors

It seemed from the beginning that it was assumed everyone in the class took AP biology before; there were things I was pretty unaware of all throughout the course that were for the most part presented as prerequisite knowledge. I felt that the tests did not at all reflect the course material or lectures; the lectures were extremely focused on the societal impacts of certain biological topics, while tests required explanation of the science, diagram drawings, etc. I think the courses biggest strength was discussion section. I felt very engaged in this setting and felt like my TA cared a lot about what we learned; most of the material I remember and continue to reflect on was from discussion section.
I think that the course could be advertised better in that the tests are very challenging.

Strengths: section discussion time
Weakness: multiple professors, felt disorganized and lack of cohesion
The strengths of this course for me were the Experience Science section and the useful review sessions before exams.
I think classes could relate to each other more
Strengths - good breadth of topics. Weaknesses - sometimes wish the lectures were more engaging.

Well organized, numerous professors that add different perspectives, 

3rd exam being the Tuesday after spring break is super tough.

The strength is the range of content. The weakness are teachers teaching the course with heavy terminology and concepts that were somehow expected to know in an intro/lower level course. Which made it extremely difficult to comprehend and when you asked questions they were also explained in terminology. The professors are extremely talented and smart. The explanations just lacked.

Strengths - lectures were recorded, slides were informative, review sessions were helpful
Weaknesses- felt like it got too technical for a non-STEM major course at times. Some of the material was very hard to grasp and not explained very well.
More clarity over what kinds of questions will be on exams (specifically, telling us whether or not we should know how to draw things). Also, some of the lecturers could be more engaging.
Definitely take the Experience Science section with Ronit. It is so cool to travel around campus and see all of the scientific things going on.

The lectures are very interesting but they are also long, and there is just a lot of information packed into each one. There arent many assignments that count towards your grade which can be both good and bad.
The review sessions were often too close to the exam itself. Additionally more practice tests would have been useful for studying.
strengths- lecturers, variety of topics
Lectures can be more explanatory. Hard to go back and review.
Not time consuming and easy to know what to do to get a good grade. Not very interesting content or engaging lecturers
The strengths were that there were multiple professors teaching, but that was also a weakness because some of the professors were much better than others.
The course is pretty monotonous, just reading off of lecture slides gets you all the information you need.

Strengths: Engelman clearly has the course well organized. When the lecture topic is interesting, the class can be a cool way to destress and learn something interesting.

Weaknesses: Often though, the lectures were not interesting. The problem was the level of detail on the science I felt we spent way too much time on the scientific functions "the bio" and not enough on the actually applicable "the world and us." To be honest, if you're in that class you are not a Science person. So learning exactly how drugs interact with the neurons is probably far less useful than learning about the health implications of drug addiction, for example.

Strengths are the topics covered, the selection covered pretty much every socially/politically important topic. Weakness was that some of the lectures were really fast paced and brushed over some more difficult topics.
It was interesting but the lectures were very disconnected from the class itself. If there were more opportunities to connect the class to section, I think I would do better on tests.

The course covered interesting material and explored relevant topics. However, due to the variation among professors, certain lectures would be filled with details that later proved unnecessary and others would gloss over topics that could have been further explained. This is more an issue of the exams, which seemed to change in variety of content covered alongside topic.
I liked the structure, could be simplified at times and better idea of what tests look like
Lecturers went a little fast sometimes! Other than that all good, section was really interesting
It touches on a wide variety of topics that are relevant to everyday life and major political and social issues.
The lectures are fine and section was fun. The tests are somewhat hard because you have to memorize a lot.

Strengths: low work level, high applicability 
Weaknesses: lack of connection between sections and lecture

I am not a science person, but I found this course to be surprisingly interesting for an easy science requirement filler. The lecturers were talented and the topics were fascinating. The workload was low which made the class low stress and enjoyable. Some weaknesses were that the professors needed to better coordinate their lectures with each other, and the TFs needed to coordinate the section content with the lectures better. The content was all over the place and often repeated throughout the year. Also, the style of lecture and test questions changed significantly from professor to professor, leading to some adjustment periods. I liked my section TF and he chose good content, but the section was often very dry since many students didn't care to contribute much.
It should be better suited to student learning.

Strengths: TFs and their help 

Weakness: slide layout can be confusing
Great lectures
I think it might have been helpful to have a few more ways to be evaluated outside of the exams and final essay.

I think it would be very helpful if some of the lecture slides/notes for the class was a bit more consistent across the lectures from different professors. For some professors, the slides were such that it was easy to pick out relevant information, whereas for others not so much. This made it challenging when studying for the exams. I also think it would be nice to have TAs who were a little bit more engaging and seemed like they at least wanted to be there a little bit, especially during the exam review sessions, which were often incredibly rushed to the point of not being useful.
I think that there could have been more engagement like practice problems, etc
It is structured very well and I liked the rotating lecturers. The pace is also good. But sometimes it got a bit complicated around very scientific units, like pain signaling.
Weaknesses: Too advanced for an Intro Biology course
Strength of the course is that low courselosd and weakness is that there are no psets but the tests are very hard

One strength of this course is the wide variety of material, so you don't have to go beyond a surface level knowledge of specific topics. In addition, the section structure of the course is nice because the sections cover discussions on themes related to the topic, not the topics themselves. Therefore, it feels much easier to participate in section. 
One disadvantage of the course is the make-up exam structure; if you miss one of the exams, you have to make it up the last week of classes, during the same week as the third exam. It's a lot of material to cover in such a short period of time.
Sections were good. Review material wasnt great.

The course is a gut, but well-developed in the sense that I actually felt engaged and learned a lot. I was even able to correct a science major on something related to neuron energy transfer, which is pretty cool.

Strengths- the different lectures made for a good change of pace during the class periods. Each brought different teaching styles and they were all experts in their fields. 
Weakness- sometimes there were a lot of complicated details on the slides that were hardly explained and never tested. Also, some lecturers made me sleepy.
This course is a typical lecture course. I particularly enjoyed the different lecturers because it created a change of pace and made it easier to retain information.
I liked the material. I think it could be improved by making it less technical in lecture and focusing more on real world applications in lecture.

The strengths are that all the information was given clearly through the lectures
The weakness was probably review sessions.
Great lecturers, good asynchronous materials, and helpful discussion sections.

Strengths:
- TA was great
- clear
- minimum homework

Weaknesses:
- not all profs the same
- not enough practice material

It would be helpful to have more preparation for the exams, other than one review session. Sometimes slides and lectures were hard to follow, and though I really enjoyed section, it might help to have some days where we went through the material in more detail.

I found that the lack of review of lecture material in section made the course feel disconnected and did not offer as much student support as it had the opportunity to in a smaller group setting. I did appreciate the class' more wholistic view of science in the real world, which felt more approachable to non-science majors that this course was especially tailored for. I most enjoyed the final research paper and its open-ended application to the materials we had studied in the course.
THe level of detail presented in lectures were sometimes difficult to keep up with

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, because the lecture topics were interesting and there aren't weekly problem sets. The three exam's can be each a quite a handful because the material can be hard.

Under no god-forsaken circumstance would I recommend this course to any student since that would be an abuse of their well-being, and absolute waste of their time. I am not being humorous or taking my aggression out here, this class is absolutely horrid and I wish someone told me. On a serious note, this class is unnecessarily challenging despite the catfish of the easy syllabus. Please, trust me, there are better science credits out there for my fellow non-stem majors.
I would recommend this course to a non-science major interested in learning about biology. It is a good Sc credit, but not completely a gut - you must study for the exams.
No, this is not the most interesting science credit out there.
Yes if they want an intro science credit
Yes if you like science and especially bio. Very interesting and fun class.

Take it for the science gut! You won't have fun or learn anything really exciting/useful, but we gotta fill those distributional requirements! The only real "work" that you need to put into the class is studying for the exams (three, non-cumulative) about two days in advance. If you can, try to sign up for the "experience section." We got to go on some interesting field trips and conduct a few experiments that other sections did not have a chance to participate in. These section experiences were probably the most interesting part of the course.
Pick a different science class if you need to fulfill your credit requirement. Tests ended up being tough.
Yes, great class to learn about biology and how it's relevant to the world right now.
I would recommend it, however, I would also warn them because although the class was incredibly interesting, the tests were not accurate and did not reflect the lectures or review sessions.
I would recommend taking this course if you need a gut science. I would say however to take it in the spring term not the fall as it is curved in the spring.
I would recommend this course if you're interested in bio topics as a humanities/non-STEM major. I would not recommend this course to STEM majors.
Yes
While this class may have been a gut during COVID, it definitely exceeded workload expectations. There are two lectures per week, but the test were oftentimes more difficult than expected.

Yes and no - as a non-stem major I think this was a good choice for finding a class with interesting material. But keep in mind, it is NOT a gut. Its not an insanely difficult class, but you will have to work hard to do well.

If you do take this course, TAKE THE EXPERIENCE SCIENCE SECTION. I took it randomly (didnt even know it was an option), but it truly was the highlight of the class. We got to do a number of cool things that no other section got to do, like see a lab, see behind the scenes at the Peabody museum, and see a room full of human brains, among other things. TAKE THIS SECTION, TAKE THIS SECTION, TAKE THIS SECTION.
Yes, it's pretty straightforward for non-bio students and conveys understanding of biological concepts in social context.
yes
No. Not if youre looking for an easy or interesting or coherently organized course
No, there are better science credits
No - stay away, unless you have a background in biology. This course doesnt have a lot of work but the tests are very difficult

I would not recommend this course to anyone who is not a STEM major. I feel like this course did not succeed in being a gateway for humanities majors into science like the course description said. I feel like I gained very little from this course, but I loved my discussion section. I think the tests did not reflect lecture material and were far too focused on scientific processes rather than real world examples, impact on society, etc like the lectures were.
I would recommend this course to a student especially if you were looking for a science credit with a workload that is less than your average Yale class
Yes, only if they are interested in biology. It is not very easy for someone who is not interested in the topic.
Yes
Yes! I think this course is great, especially for students looking for a science class that wont cause mass amounts of stress.
Yes if they are interested in bio but don't want to take a higher level science class
Yes. Good science credit, you just have to apply yourself and the topics are interesting.
If you need a science gut sure. If you like stem, yes definitely.

It is a good science credit but involves a lot of work. Three exams that covered a lot of technical-scientific material in addition to a final paper that had to be researched extensively is not very easy.
If youre interested in learning more about biology and have the time in your semester to dedicate consistently to studying the material, you should take it.

Definitely worthwhile to take this class, it's incredibly worthwhile to be conversant in basic science which this course achieves. It is also great to learn about the science going on at Yale and get to hear lectures from so many different professors. The workload is fairly light, you just need to study the lecture content well for the 3 exams.

Yes I would recommend this course if you want a surface level introduction to biology. It can be considered a gut for STEM majors, but for the social sciences and humanities, it requires a lot of memorization.
If the student is a non-stem major looking to take a science course that is manageable, I would recommend this course.
Yes, great for non stem majors, a very broad overview of biology.
yes good science
Not really. It's interesting but science can be much more fascinating.
No, it feels like a waste of a credit
I would recommend this course because it gives a good foundation on the basics of biology and the issues surrounding it in the world today.
It is a fine course if you need a science credit, but there are probably other courses to look at. If you are interested in biology then I would definitely recommend.
Eh if you need a SCI credit, sure. But its not the easiest way to get it. Also, if you've taken enough bio before, the class is easy but mindnumbing - which can catch up with you in the end.
Yes, really interesting and catered towards non stem people
Yes! If you are interesting in things other than science, you can explore them in the research papers and section.
Absolutely

I would recommend this course to another student if they were interested in learning more about the modern field of biology and how that connects to society. The level of detail works well for students in the humanities/social sciences as it does not expect prior knowledge but goes sufficiently deep as to explain the topics well. I would note that, despite the lack of problem sets, the three exams and final paper create an inconsistent but substantial workload.
Yes great course and great science credit
Yes, definitely a good one for non science majors
Yes. For a nonstem major this is a really good science option.
If you are looking for an easy science, take this class!
I would recommend the course to another student who does not have much background in science, but would like to learn more.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is an interesting course that provides some basic biology knowledge if you are someone who knows little about science and doesn't plan on taking higher-level science courses. The workload is low overall, but the tests do require careful studying. Also section can be kind of boring and dry, but it is what you make of it.
If you need a gut science, perhaps. But even then, it requires serious studying for exams.
This class was harder than I thought it would be, so maybe not to other students who struggle with science like I do
Yes. Very interesting
I would recommend it. It was an interesting way to learn about the science of many topics without being overwhelmed, especially as a non science major.

I think this is the default gutty science credit for non-STEM folks, when it really doesn't have to be. There are a lot of other great courses out there if you do some digging and just because a science course has lower workload does not necessarily mean it will definitely be easierat least conceptually.
if you need a science credit and are a non science student i recommend
Yes, it's a great class for non-STEM majors who want to learn a bit more about science in a nonintimidating setting.
Depends, if you are looking for a generally easy Science credit, then no.
No because the class is hard without psets
I would recommend this course to another student if they're looking for a Science credit, but might be willing to put a little bit more work in. Having a background such as AP Bio is a plus.
Yes. Good course with lower workload
I would recommend this course to any student who has a basic understanding of high school biology, is looking for a gut, and wants to learn something.
Pretty easy science class. Would recommend

I would recommend it if you need a science credit but aren't a science person. The tests arent too bad if you go to the review sessions and there is almost no work besides the final paper and the sections.
I would recommend this course because the content was so impactful. The content will serve any student well in everyday life.
Yes, I would recommend this to someone who isn't a stem major who needs a science credit.
Yes, because this course taught me a lot about biology and gave me information that I could use in the future.
Yes, it was a very good study of biology.
Yes! For a non-science major, it was an informative intro to biology course. The TAs were great, and it was fun to discuss in section.

I recommend this course to non-STEM majors heavily. It fulfills a science requirement and is not too taxing. It also gives you a good understanding of science topics that are likely to be relevant in your life.

extras.title: MB&B 105 01/MCDB 105 01 - Biology, the World, and Us
